section.title: AMQP
section.p: Acronym for Advanced Message Queuing Protocol.

section.title: Apache ANT
section.p: A software tool for automating software build processes. See Ant for more info.

section.title: Apache Maven
section.p: A build automation tool typically used for Java projects. See Maven for more info.

section.title: app
section.p: Any application software intended for instantiation in Application Lifecycle Service. At minimum it consists of the application, expressed in a dynamic language, plus a configuration file named manifest.yml.

section.title: Avahi
section.p: An implementation of multicast DNS and related protocols.

section.title: cluster
section.p: A set of interconnected physical processors or virtual machines, managed at least conceptually as a single entity but otherwise operating autonomously. Historically the term carried a variety of proprietary meanings, but came into general use with the rapid development of supercomputing based upon Beowulf Clusters. An Application Lifecycle Service cluster is one in which role are assigned or replicated to multiple cluster nodes.

section.title: component
section.p: Within Application Lifecycle Service, the term component is used when naming a discrete part of the Application Lifecycle Service server. For example, a role is made up of one or more components.

section.title: container
section.p: A lightweight form of virtualization which provides resource isolation and secure separation for multiple instances of the same base system. According to circumstances it may be used in addition to or instead of hypervisor virtualization.

section.title: CPAN
section.p: Acronym for Comprehensive Perl Archive Network.

section.title: doozerd
section.p: A consistent distributed data store. Used for cluster management in Application Lifecycle Service. (see Doozer project on GitHub)

section.title: DHCP
section.p: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. The DHCP service is used to allocate IP addresses to clients on demand and to supply other basic network information they need, such as the addresses of a default router and DNS server.

section.title: DNS
section.p: Domain Name System. Resolves domain names to IP addresses.

section.title: dnsmasq
section.p: A lightweight server for locally integrating DNS with DHCP/BOOTP.

section.title: dynamic DNS
section.p: A means of rapidly updating the Domain Name System, possibly making use of RFC 2136 Dynamic Updates.

section.title: filesystem
section.p: In Application Lifecycle Service, filesystem refers to persistent storage accessed by an application service specified in manifest.yml through a server which has been assigned the filesystem role.

section.title: JSON
section.p: A notation for structured text data, acronym for JavaScript Object Notation.

section.title: MBUS
section.p: Application Lifecycle Service's implementation of an RFC 3259 message queue used for interprocess communication. See also: NATS.

section.title: memcached
section.p: Free & open source, high-performance, distributed memory object caching system, generic in nature, but intended for use in speeding up dynamic web applications by alleviating database load. (see Memcached project page)

section.title: micro cloud
section.p: A preconfigured Application Lifecycle Service virtual machine image consisting of a single generic node enabled for all the roles necessary for basic operation, but with no pre-installed apps or servicess.

section.title: mongodb
section.p: A popular noSQL database management system.

section.title: multicast DNS
section.p: A distributed means of configuring DNS by multicast discovery. It is supported on Application Lifecycle Service micro cloud servers using Avahi.

section.title: mysql
section.p: A relational database management system.

section.title: NAT
section.p: Acronym for Network Address Translation.

section.title: NATS
section.p: In Application Lifecycle Service, a publish-subscribe message system implemented as a process called nats-server which listens on a network interface, normally on port 4222/tcp. Messages published across the network to a particular MBUS queue managed by the nats-server are communicated to clients which are subscribed to that queue.

section.title: Nginx
section.p: Nginx is a high-performance, event-driven web server.

section.title: Node
section.p: An Application Lifecycle Service node is a single processing host in a cluster. It is typically a virtual machine running under a hypervisor.

section.title: OVF
section.p: Acronym for Open Virtualization Format, a specification for virtual machine images developed by the DMTF industry consortium.

section.title: PaaS
section.p: Acronym for Platform as a Service.

section.title: pip
section.p: A tool for installing and managing Python packages, such as those found in the Python Package Index. It's a replacement for easy_install. See pip-installer for more information.

section.title: PyPM
section.p: PyPM is the binary package manager for ActivePython. It is usually the fastest and most reliable way of installing PyPI packages for your Application Lifecycle Service applications. The PyPM repository hosts almost all of the Python packages registered in PyPI and includes their latest versions. See PyPM for more information.

section.title: Polipo
section.p: A lightweight caching web proxy intended for small applications.

section.title: postgresql
section.p: A relational database management system.

section.title: private PaaS
section.p: A private PaaS is one which is hosted on your private cloud, behind your firewall.

section.title: RabbitMQ
section.p: A message broker subsystem which implements AMQP.

section.title: Redis
section.p: An implementation of memory resident key-value store.

section.title: resolvconf
section.p: A system configuration tool typically used by hook scripts at boot time. See the resolvconf man page for details.

section.title: role
section.p: Each node in an Application Lifecycle Service cluster may be assigned certain selectable capabilities within the Application Lifecycle Service architecture. These capabilities are called roles, and are usually denoted in lowercase. Examples of essential roles are router, primary, controller, and dea. In addition, there are role groups (for convenience) such as data-services that represent all data-services. (postgresql mysql rabbit mongodb redis filesystem memcached)

section.title: service
section.p: In Application Lifecycle Service, a service is a type of role that may be provisioned on a server and accessed by an application as specified in manifest.yml.

section.title: supervisord
section.p: A process control system used by Application Lifecycle Service internally. (see Supervisor project page)

section.title: tty console
section.p: The hypervisor window which provides serial console access to one of its virtual machines.

section.title: YAML
section.p: A notation for structured text data, acronym for YAML Ain't Markup Language, used in manifest.yml configuration files.
